newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila call loan rate unchanged in liquid market.
newsitem.headline: Manila call loan rate unchanged in liquid market.

text.p: Philippine interbank call loan rates stayed unchanged at an average of 11.09375 percent on Tuesday in a liquid market, traders said.
Dones rates were at 11.25 percent to 11.03125, with volume thinning to 11.621 billion pesos from 22.308 billion.
"We had expected rates to go up," said a foreign bank dealer, since the Central Bank stepped up its sales of reverse repos.
"But this was offset by maturities," said the same dealer.
Another dealer said banks had remained liquid because they had not been investing heavily in government securities.
Banks had adopted a wait-and-see attitude in anticipation interest rates would go up due to the recent increase in domestic oil prices, she said.
In mid-October, the government raised fuel prices by an average of 30.72 centavos per litre. Analysts expected the fuel price hike to spur inflation.
In the secondary market trading of T-bills, traders said banks were selling their short-term bills in favour of the one-year bills which carry more attractive rates.
